__Text__.text: How would Joe measure changes to his energy storage?

Under Additional Dragoon Problems in the main window, make sure that the Problem Category option reads Energy balance and the Problem option reads Energy balance 0. Click on the Open problem button, boxed in the screenshot below.
The following model should appear. This is your workspace for the Energy Balance - Level 0 problem. Here, you will model different systems and graph them!
It doesn't look like much, but that is because you still need to create your nodes.

__Question__.gen: On your computer, complete the following steps to create a Dragoon model for Energy Balance.

__Text__.text: To start defining a node, click on the Create Node button in the top left corner. The following window should pop up:
The blank dropdown menu labaled Description is for the name and description for the node. Select energy stored in Joe's body each day.

A message should pop up saying "Green means you chose the author's answer. God job!" This message is from the tutoring system. It knows that the correct model is and will help you create it. When your blank turns green, it means you have done this correctly. Click on OK.
Next, select the node Type. Try choosing Parameter.
Oops-- be careful! If you choose the wrong type, the box will turn red.

The correct answer in this case is Accumulator. The problem gives this to you, but often, you will have to read through the text on the left of the screen and figure it out on your own. See the Key Terms & Concepts at the beginning of this workbook to review node types.
Input the correct initial value. (If you input the incorrect value more than two times, the box will turn yellow with the correct choice.)
Enter 345000 for the Initial Value and select calories for Units. Note that Dragoon does not understand commas, so enter 345000 and not 345,000.
The next option you should see is Inputs followed by mathematical operations (+,-,*,/). Skip these for now and focus on the Expression box.

The Expression box is where you define the calculation for your node. To do this, you can add Inputs, which are the other nodes in your problem, as well as click on mathematical operations to put them in your calculation. At any point in your node creation, when you think you are done with your expresion, press Check Expression to receive feedback on your answer. above the Expression box, you will se the beginning part of the calculation. In this case, you should see new energy stored = old energy stored +. Finish this calcualtion with inputs from the box. In this case, add the input energy balance by clicking on the dropdown option for Inputs and select the correct response. Click Check Expression. The expression box should turn green if you put in the correct calculation.
When you have finished and all boxes are completed (Inputs will never be completed because it just contains options for the expression), click Done in teh bottom right corner.

Congratulations! You have created your first node. You should immediately notice two things. First, another node has been created in addition to the energy stored one you made. This is because you used it in your calculation in the Description. Anything that hasn’t been created yet but you use in your calculation should automatically appear when you are done defining your node. Second, you may notice that the node you created, energy stored, has a solid, yellow border around it. The border will change depending on how well you did in creating your node. The border may be solid (signifying the node has been defined completely) or dotted (signifying the node isn’t completely defined and you won’t be able to graph your model). In addition, the border may be red (you didn’t correctly define the node on your own), green (you correctly defined the node on your own), or yellow (the answer was given for you on some nodes). If you enter everything in the node correctly on your first try, then the whole node turns green. Shoot for making your nodes all green!
Go ahead and double-click the blue energy balance triangle and try to define the node on your own! Hint, the answer is in the text on the left of the screen.
When you are finished, you should see  this message. It's time to graph your model!
Click on the Graph button on the top menu bar. You should see this:

If you haven’t finished completing your model, you cannot graph it and the following message will pop up. When this happens, look for nodes that have dotted lines around them. This means that they are not completely defined and need to be finished.
When you have successfully finished creating your model, the graph window should pop up when you click on the button. Now you can answer the following questions.

__Question__.gen: In the graph window, vary the values of energy balance and initial energy stored by dragging the sliders back and forth along the lines (boxed below) or by typing in different values in the boxes (boxed below).

__Text__.text:
Notice that the graph can change with these values. A red line should pop up showing you the author’s solution. The value that you have changed by varying the values should be green. When you’re done playing with the values, answer the following questions.

What is the vertical axis on the graph?
What happens to the graph if you change the energy balance from 100 calories to 300 calories? What does this mean?
When you finish with these problems, close the graphing window and open the table by clicking on the Table button on the top menu bar.

Day 0:
Why are your answers so different for questions 5d & 5f? What does this mean?

__Question__.gen:
The energy balance of your body is the difference between the energy you add to your body by ingesting food and the energy you subtract from your body by physical exercise and other activities. When the energy you ingest exactly equals the energy you expend, the energy balance is zero. When the energy you ingest is greater than the energy you expend, the energy balance is positive and the excess energy is added to the body's energy stores. When you consume less energy than you expend, the energy balance is negative and your body makes up the deficit by withdrawing energy from storage. The energy balance can change each day. Thus, if the energy balance is positive on a particular day, then the energy stored goes up by that amount during the day. If the energy balance is negative, then the energy stored goes down.

Joe's next model of his energy balance is more complex. It makes energy balance a function of energy ingested and energy expended. Eventually, this will allow him to vary them separately. For instance, he can see what happens if he keeps his diet the same (and hence energy ingested is the same as it is now) but he does more exercise (so his energy expended is higher than it is now). However, for now he assumes that his daily expenditure is 2100 calories and his daily ingestion nets him 1989 calories.

rows: Energy expended daily; initial value = 2100 cal.
Energy stored in the body; initial value = 345000 cal.
Energy ingested daily; initial value = 1989 calories
difference between ingestion and expenditure of energy per day
